body.p:
To His Excellincy B. Magoffin
Governor of Kentucky

Your Petitiioners John Bell, R Varble, & Patrick Fitzpatrick, state, that at the January term of the city Court of Louisville (1862) they were each fine two hundred dollars, upon an Indictment for permitting Gaming in their house. They are Keepers of Coffee & boarding houses, The Gaming complained of was not for money, but sometimes their boarders & neighbors played Games of "Euchre," "whist" & "seven up" for drinks & cigars, in a sociable & friendly manner, They state that, they never permitted Gaming for money in their houses, So soon as they were advised, that such Gaming were against the law, They appeared in court & confessed, with the and now state that they will hereafter prohibit such violations of the law They are poor and unable to pay said fines Wherefore they respectfully, ask your Exellency to remit said fines & as in duty bound will ever pray& --

Respectfully
John Bell
R Varble
Patrick Fitzpatrick

The above petition fairly states the case of petitioners. They live in the same neighborhood, and are clean, industrious and Except in the above instance I know of no violation of the law having been committed by either of them. I am satisfied they will hereafter refrain as promised & considering the circumstances & character of Petitioners, and the nature of the offence, I respectfully unite with them &c
The Petitioners confessed Judgement in Each case but from facts stated to me & on which I rely I think the fines should be remitted.

Louisville City Ct
$200 each } gaming
Jno. Bell & others
Respd Mos
Issd Jany 17. 1862
